title: Foreign-born mothers give birth to fewer children in the UK for the first time in almost 30 YEARS
text:
The number of children born into the UK to foreign-born mothers fell for the first time in almost 30 years last year, official statistics show.

Non-UK born women accounted for 28.2 per cent of live births in 2018, a fall from 28.4 percent the year before, according to the Office for National Statistics - the first decline since 1990.

The number of births of children of foreign-born men also fell for the first time since 2008, the first year that figures were collected.

It came amid a 3.2 percent overall decline in the number of children born in the UK, with 14,911 fewer births in 2018 over the year before. There was a 3.7 per cent drop among births to non-UK-born women, a drop of 7,082.

Poland, Pakistan and Romania remained the most common countries of origin for foreign-born mothers having children, but the figures for Poland and Pakistan fell, while the number of Romanian mothers rose.

In total, just over a third (33.8 per cent) of babies born in England and Wales in 2018 had at least one parent who was born outside the UK. This was also a small decrease on the previous year.

The most common countries of birth of non-UK-born mothers having children in the UK in the last 10 years

Kathryn Littleboy of the ONS said these parents 'could be long-time residents who moved here when they were younger, or those who moved to the UK more recently.'

She added: 'Poland and Pakistan remain the most common countries of birth for non-UK-born mothers and fathers respectively.

'Romania is now the second most common country of birth for non-UK-born fathers and the third for non-UK-born mothers.'

Figures on live births to foreign-born women date back to 1969, when the proportion for England and Wales stood at 11.7 per cent.

The number first rose above 15 per cent in 2000, above 20 per cent in 2005 and above 25 per cent in 2010.

For the third year in a row, Brent in London was the local authority in England with the highest percentage of live births to non-UK-born mothers at 75.4 per cent.

Copeland in Cumbria had the lowest - 3.0 per cent.

The local authority outside London with the highest proportion of non-UK-born mothers was Slough in Berkshire, with 65.2 per cent.

The ONS report released today added: 'Romania has been the highest climber since 2012, when it appeared for the first time in the top 10.

'In 2007 (when Romania joined the EU) there were only 1,248 live births in England and Wales to Romanian-born mothers.

'Despite the overall decrease in the number of births to foreign-born women in recent years, the number of births to Romanian-born mothers rose from 13,717 in 2017 to 15,196 in 2018.

'As a result of the recent increases in births to Romanian-born mothers, Romania became the sixth most common country of birth for non-UK-born mothers in England and Wales in 2013, before rising to fourth in 2015 and third in 2017.'
